Smallest voice leading between two sets

minimizeVL.Rd

Given a source set and a goal to move to, find the "strongly crossing-free" voice leading from source to goal with smallest size.

Usage

minimizeVL(source, goal, method = "taxicab", no_ties = FALSE, edo = 12)

Arguments

source

Numeric vector, the pitch-class set at the start of your voice leading

goal

Numeric vector, the pitch-class set at the end of your voice leading

method

What distance metric should be used? Defaults to "taxicab" but can be "euclidean".

no_ties

If multiple VLs are equally small, should only one be returned? Defaults to FALSE, which is generally what a human user should want. Some functions that call minimize_VL need TRUE for predictable shapes of the returned value.

edo

Number of unit steps in an octave. Defaults to 12.

Value

Numeric array. In most cases, a vector the same length as source; or a vector of NA the same length as source if goal and source have different lengths. If no_ties=FALSE and multiple voice leadings are equivalent, the array can be a matrix with m rows where m is the number of equally small voice leadings.

Examples

c_major <- c(0,4,7)
ab_minor <- c(8,11,3)
minimizeVL(c_major, ab_minor)
#> [1] -1 -1  1

diatonic_scale <- c(0,2,4,5,7,9,11)
minimizeVL(diatonic_scale, tn(diatonic_scale, 7))
#> [1] 0 0 0 1 0 0 0

d_major <- c(2,6,9)
minimizeVL(c_major, d_major)
#>      [,1] [,2] [,3]
#> [1,]    2    2    2
#> [2,]   -3   -2   -1
minimizeVL(c_major, d_major, no_ties=TRUE)
#> [1] 2 2 2
minimizeVL(c_major, d_major, method="euclidean", no_ties=FALSE)
#> [1] 2 2 2

minimizeVL(c(0,4,7,10),c(7,7,11,2),method="euclidean")
#>      [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4]
#> [1,]   -1   -2    0   -3
#> [2,]    2    3    0    1
minimizeVL(c(0,4,7,10),c(7,7,11,2),method="euclidean", no_ties=TRUE)
#> [1] -1 -2  0 -3
